{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3168259,"name":"","username":"Sylent","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sylent/{size}/180576_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-20T02:13:32.854Z","cooked":"

I’ve been trying to get my led strip to work by plugging it into the RoboRIO’s pwm but the lights haven’t been turning on.

Using these lights (1m/60 LEDs) I plugged the power wires into the 5V/2A port on the vrm. I then plugged the signal wire of the cable into the signal pin on the rio. I wrote some code to set every led to a dim red (rgb(80, 0, 0)), but I didn’t see anything and the vrm was drawing ~0 amps.

Before this, however, I plugged the wire (power, data, ground) directly into the pwm (data, power, ground) port without checking to make sure which wire was power or data, so I plugged the data wire into the power pin. Would that have broken things? Also, occasionally with this configuration, the first led would change to a bright green.

Has anyone else experienced something like this?

My other theory is that there isn’t enough current to power all 60 LEDs, so I could try cutting it in half and even power it over the roborio pwm port like this but I’m really unsure about it working.

Here is the light strip code I’ve written:

class LightStrip:
    def __init__(self, port: int, length=60) -> None:
        self.light_strip_buffer = [AddressableLED.LEDData() for _ in range(length)]
        self.light_strip = AddressableLED(port)
        self.light_strip.setLength(length)
        self.light_strip.setData(self.light_strip_buffer)
        self.light_strip.start()

        # for testing
        self.setRGB(80, 0, 0)

    def update(self) -> None:
        """Call periodically to update the light strip"""
        self.light_strip.setData(self.light_strip_buffer)

    def setRGB(self, r: int, g: int, b: int) -> None:
        for led in self.light_strip_buffer:
            led.setRGB(r, g, b)
    # ...
class Robot(TimedRobot):
    # ...
    def robotPeriodic(self):
        # also for testing
        self.light_strip.setRGB(80, 0, 0)
        self.light_strip.update()
","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2023-03-20T02:15:58.187Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":191,"reads":167,"readers_count":166,"score":988.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":430915,"topic_slug":"led-strip-into-roborio-not-working","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.amazon.ca/dp/B088BRY2SH","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":30},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/is-it-possible-to-plug-led-strips-into-the-roborio/428387/40","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Is it possible to plug led strips into the roborio?","clicks":7}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55795,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3985 - Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/led-strip-into-roborio-not-working/430915/1","custom_user_title":"3985 - Programming Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3168272,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-20T02:31:11.763Z","cooked":"

Careful. 1M long, fully lit will use 18 watts, or 3.6 amps at 5v.

Though that doesnt explain why you can’t light just a dim red, since that should be 1.2 amps or less.

It’s very possible you have accidentally fried the LED strip, or just have a bad strip. There doesn’t seem to be anything particularly wrong with how you have it setup right now, but as Tom said above, you should be cautious of the amount of current you are drawing.

Check your signal wire, we had a similar issue and it was because we assumed the tail for the LEDs just matched the pwm ports

Yeah we assumed the same. Were you able to just swap them around to get it working or did you have to use another strip?

I actually fried the same strip before this one by accidentally plugging in 12V instead of 5V causing blue smoke .
The one I have now doesn’t do anything like spark up, just sits there lifeless. I don’t think it’s fried; at least not in the same way.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2023-03-20T04:16:15.222Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":90,"readers_count":89,"score":48.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":430915,"topic_slug":"led-strip-into-roborio-not-working","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":51083,"username":"anon37142155","name":null,"avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/f08c70/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55795,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3985 - Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/led-strip-into-roborio-not-working/430915/6","custom_user_title":"3985 - Programming Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3168328,"name":"Mr. Siefen | 453","username":"kingc95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kingc95/{size}/226662_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-20T04:22:31.821Z","cooked":"

Those definitely are the “addressable” 5v variety we use as well. But we have done it a couple of different ways depending on how the season was going at the time.

We have had bad luck with directly controlling it via the RoboRio before and because of that we learned a few work around methods you could try to salvage/test the ws2812b strips.

If you have an Arduino Mega/Uno you can connect the strip to it and run the fastLED library demos and see if the strip is functional with a known good code set. If this works but the roboRio method is still not working then you can move onto the next step.

At this point we figured out that we could use Bit Flags with I/O lines that we would scan on the Arduino and set from the roboRio and control which premade effect/pattern would run. Example: there are 3 I/o lines total. 1 is for color red/blue hi/lo, then 2 for selecting the pattern hi/hi = solid, hi/lo = slow blink, lo/lo = off

This was easier for us since we had used the fastLED and arduinos previously for off season projects and the game design challenge in 2021. That being said it’s not the most simple thing for people who aren’t already spending time on Arduino so idk if I could recommend it as the best answer. It is an answer that did work for us though

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2023-03-20T04:22:31.821Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":84,"readers_count":83,"score":41.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":430915,"topic_slug":"led-strip-into-roborio-not-working","display_username":"Mr. Siefen | 453","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20632,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mr. Siefen"},"post_url":"/t/led-strip-into-roborio-not-working/430915/7","custom_user_title":"Mr. Siefen","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3168329,"name":"Niko 319","username":"Niko_319","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/niko_319/{size}/168981_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-20T04:24:28.732Z","cooked":"

Swapped and worked great

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2023-03-20T04:24:28.732Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":69,"readers_count":68,"score":13.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":430915,"topic_slug":"led-strip-into-roborio-not-working","display_username":"Niko 319","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":55795,"username":"Sylent","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sylent/{size}/180576_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":32213,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/led-strip-into-roborio-not-working/430915/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3168333,"name":"","username":"Sylent","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sylent/{size}/180576_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-20T04:34:50.391Z","cooked":"

I was curious about this so I was about to try doing exactly this - controlling the LEDs using fastLED on an Uno. I didn’t end up doing it because I assumed that if they didn’t work through the rio then it wouldn’t work over the Ardruino but I guess I could try it.

I’ve been thinking about communicating with the Ardruino over i2c but bit flags would be fine for premade effects. It would be great if every LED could be controlled by the rio though. I’m pretty sure I saw an Ardruino program that just forwarded the signals from the rio to the LED strip but I can’t find it…

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2023-03-20T04:34:50.391Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":67,"readers_count":66,"score":38.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":430915,"topic_slug":"led-strip-into-roborio-not-working","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":20632,"username":"kingc95","name":"Mr. Siefen | 453","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kingc95/{size}/226662_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55795,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3985 - Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/led-strip-into-roborio-not-working/430915/9","custom_user_title":"3985 - Programming Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3168334,"name":"Mr. Siefen | 453","username":"kingc95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kingc95/{size}/226662_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-20T04:41:33.926Z","cooked":"

We looked at i2c and serial but the overhead for the coding team would be too much at their knowledge level at the time. I could do it but that’s a coach writing code and even though it just “LEDs” that’s no excuse to have adults do the work. So the bit flags were the best short term answer. It’s better than nothing but is super low tech and something I remembered from some old robotic sensors I’ve used in the past with a ReadyToRead and ReadyToSend like pair combo. I didn’t even want it to be that complicated so we dropped it down to a one way channel without any collision detection for messages and just a long loop time.

USB serial is pretty good and since LEDs are not usually a “system critical” thing you can worry less about the connection being shaken and losing some data along the way. We haven’t gotten to LEDs yet this year but we may try this method again over the bit flagging if they get far enough ahead. This year’s coders impressed me by getting sysid to run almost correctly without me directing it step by step.

Edit: the semi-psuedo code logic is something like this

Setup:

start the led strip and setup the connection

set the brightness and initial pin settings for inputs

clear the ledBuffer

Loop:

Read the input lines

While (animation is running):
Blocking animation code that will run one full loop without interrupting)

Wait if it’s a timed animation with a specific frame rate use (1000/fps)

This was super simple and was enough to indicate the alliance color and some arm set points for climbing last year. On the RoboRio side we actually would poll the Drive Station data for the current alliance color and set the color at robotInit. After that we only had to set the 2 digital IO lines once per loop and leave them there so the animation would just loop over and over until the lines changed.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2023-03-20T04:48:07.973Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":68,"readers_count":67,"score":43.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":430915,"topic_slug":"led-strip-into-roborio-not-working","display_username":"Mr. Siefen | 453","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":55795,"username":"Sylent","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sylent/{size}/180576_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20632,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mr. Siefen"},"post_url":"/t/led-strip-into-roborio-not-working/430915/10","custom_user_title":"Mr. Siefen","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3168340,"name":"","username":"Karlht","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/k/6bbea6/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-20T05:06:39.136Z","cooked":"

Usually these strips on Amazon come with a USB connector and remote to turn them on, which is a great way to make sure they work without needing code.

Also, these led strips on Amazon will be soldered very badly which can lead to the leds not making contact. A quick way to test this is to press into the leds to force contact but resoldering will obviously be better.
